Post_Title: Christianity is a man made religion, and most Christians don’t even know what they believe in.
post_text:
I mean other than having 50+ different types of bibles, why is the King James edition the most heavily circulated bible in the world? Because it’s man made, and King James adjusted it to push his political agenda. People have been altering the original bible for so long, that Christians are now blind followers to whatever man made book they’re presented. 

They don’t have any sense of standard, which would be the original bible. Ask a Christian who they believe in as God. Some might tell you just God himself, some might tell you Jesus, some might tell you God and Jesus, some might tell you Jesus is the direct son of God, some might tell you Jesus is God, and some might tell you they believe in a variation of the holy trinity. Obviously there’s no consistency in Christianity. If Christianity was true, there wouldn’t be so much ambiguity in something as simple as “Who is God?“ That’s literally the most basic question of religion. All these variations came about because it is a man made religion and man is not perfect.

To continue, why do some Christians (usually the more devout) abstain from alcohol and pork, while some Christians indulge in it in religious ceremonies? Jesus never ate pork or drank alcohol, so as a follower of the teachings of Jesus Christ, why do so many Christians say it’s permissible? Even in some versions of the Bible (usually the older ones), it directly says to abstain from pork and alcohol. It sounds like man altered the bible to make it permissible to sin, and spread it as gospel.

Why do Christians say “Jesus died for our sins”? Where did this come from, because it’s not written in the Bible. What’s the point in religion then if “Jesus died for our sins?” Is nobody held accountable for there deeds then? Did Jesus die for Hitler’s sins? Should Hitler go to heaven despite killing 6 million people because Jesus died for his sins? Again, another man made piece of rhetoric used by Christians as an excuse to sin.

As I got older, I realized how many contradictions and alterations are in Christianity. I noticed that the Christian community brushes off major contradictions and errors so nonchalantly, like it’s nothing, but we should always ask questions. If something is really true, shouldn’t it be able to stand the test of questioning? I finally came to learn that Christianity is a bunch of baloney. It’s contradiction after contradiction. Sure, there’s some parts of it that probably are unaltered words from God and his messenger, but major parts of it are definitely man made.

Threads.Reply_Text:
**I mean other than having 50+ different types of bibles, why is the King James edition the most heavily circulated bible in the world? Because it’s man made, and King James adjusted it to push his political agenda. People have been altering the original bible for so long, that Christians are now blind followers to whatever man made book they’re presented.**

lol... no. well it is clear 'christian's' are not the only one who doesn't understand what they believe.

As bibles even the kjv and it's derivatives are not translated that way. You do not seem to know we have the compilation of hand written manuscripts from which the kjv was translated. ( Textus Receptus ) these compilations are called codices.

As stated they are a completion of the original manuscripts in the koine Greek that the bibles are translated from. There are several codacees from which the majority of the holy bibles are translated from. at the time of the KJV Textus Receptus (the majority text) was what was available.

since then two other older and more complete codices were found which did in fact change the translation a little between bibles translated from the Textus Receptus. The commandment "thou shalt not kill" for instance was derived from the Textus Receptus. this order is a prohibition on the taking of all human life. where as text from the Sinaiticus or the Vaticanus commands you shall not murder. which is the unauthorized taking of human life. that is one of the biggest changes in the text.

So politics played very little into the translation as again there are several bibles translated from the Textus Receptus and aside from being translated to a active dialect very little separates the kjv and a modern bible from the same codex.

**They don’t have any sense of standard, which would be the original bible.**

again... maybe google how bibles are made. there is a standard. but as any people who speak more than one language will tell you there are two primary forms of translation one is literal which gives you word for word which alot of time does not correct for grammar or syntax. meaning alot of the time if you were to hear a literal translation it would not make sense or the word placement in a sentence would be out of order. (like talking with yoda) then you have a subjective or contextual translation based on communicating the idea of the message rather than a nonsensical word for word.

But the problem with a contextual translation it heavily depends on the translators understanding of the subject matter. or any social filters they may put the text through.

The holy bible is about 75% literal and 25% contextual as it try and puts the wording in a common use understanding but at the same time tries to preserve as much of the orginal text as possible. which is why it is o important to be able to read/use a lexicon along side the bible so you can look up the greek words and see alternate meanings/usages.

Now that said there are many denominationally specific bibles as well. these can be a 50/50% mix or they can be 80% personal interpretation/interpretation filter through a church doctrine with 20% original material.

Holy bible tend to be higher original content bibles.

**Ask a Christian who they believe in as God. Some might tell you just God himself, some might tell you Jesus,** No again. if you only believe in god that makes you a theist. it takes belief in christ and God the Father at a minimum to be any sort of "christian" as this terms denotes or identifies as a follower of christ.

**some might tell you God and Jesus, some might tell you Jesus is the direct son of God, some might tell you Jesus is God, and some might tell you they believe in a variation of the holy trinity.**

Once we get to the understanding Jesus was the son of God and died on the cross for our sin. we are christian. as a christian other religious details do not matter. Why? because the same atonement offered when we willfully sin is also offered when we are worship god with all of our heart, mind, spirit and strength and just get it wrong. Jesus explain this via the parable of the talents. In that we are only responsible for what was given to us/what we can understand.

Remember the word god is not God in the hebrew. the word God is eloha which is a singular masculine noun. it is the hebrew linguistic equivalent of the word god in english. Eloha is the direct translation of the word God. it is a singular masculine noun, denoting 1 deity. This word is used to describe or specifically reference God the Father God as it symbolises a singular deity.


this word was used 52 times to describe the singular deity of God the father,


STRONGS H433:

אֱלֹהַּ 57 so Deuteronomy 32:17; לֶאֱלֹהַּ Daniel 11:38 (see BD) suffix לֵאלֹהוֺ Habakkuk 1:11; elsewhere אֱלוֺהַּ noun masculine god, God. (Samaritan id., Aramaic H426 אֱלָהּ, axhXlAf  , Arabic إِله, Sabean אלה DHMl.c.; — אֱלֹהַּ as found in Hebrew probably a singular formed by inference from plural אֱלֹהִים : compare Nesl.c.) —

1. a heathen god, late usage; כָּל־אֱלוֺהַּ 2 Chronicles 32:15; Daniel 11:37; זוּ כחו לאלהו whose power is his god Habakkuk 1:11; 2 Kings 17:31 (but Qr אֱלֹהֵי), אשר הביא אֱלוֺהַּ בְּיָדוֺ who doth bring God in his hand Job 12:6 (Ew Di RVm, etc.)

2. God, used in ancient poems Deuteronomy 32:15, 17; Psalm 18:32, and on their basis an archaism in later poetry Job 3:4 + (41 times Job), Psalm 50:22; Psalm 114:7; Psalm 139:19; Proverbs 30:5; Isaiah 44:8; Habakkuk 3:3; Nehemiah 9:17 (citing Exodus 34:6 where H410 אֵל is used).

​

However..


This is not the common form of God we see in the bible. when we read "in the beginning God created.. the word they use to describe a single deity 'god' is not used but rather a plural form (more than one deity) is used. The direct correct translation in english would be 'Gods'.

The hebrew word is ĕlôhîym, el-o-heem'
אֱלֹהִים ʼĕlôhîym, el-o-heem'; plural of H433; gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative:—angels, × exceeding, God (gods) (-dess, -ly), × (very) great, judges, × mighty.


[Blueletterbible.org](https://Blueletterbible.org)

This definition which includes angels, great and mighty judges speak not of a singular deity but to an office of power.


So when translated we do not translated from the plural hebrew to the english we do not use the direct translation "Gods"  even though this is a masculine plural noun. we translate God singular. And yet the context reflects more than one 'God' through out the creation narrative. one point being at the fall when god said:22 Then the Lord God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of us in knowing good and evil. Now, lest he reach out his hand and take also of the tree of life and eat, and live forever—”22 Then the Lord God said, “Behold, the man has become like one of us in knowing good and evil. Now, lest he reach out his hand and take also of the tree of life and eat, and live forever—”

this means the typical understanding of the word God does not apply because in order for the context to denote more than two and the hebrew usage of a plural form of the word does not support the singular translation UNLESS as i pointed out the word God here is being uses as a title and not a name.
